Text Encoding Initiative

Revision of P4
Current state of play
Work to be done
Editorial work plan

This document outlines the strategy proposed by the TEI Editors for the next Revision of TEI P4, the new XML/SGML compatible version of the TEI Guidelines. Our guiding principle in drawing this up has been to avoid as far as possible any major revision of the content of the Guidelines — not because we believe such revision to be unnecessary but because we believe it should be carried out by properly constituted and chartered workgroups. We believe the topics listed here are all necessary and non-controversial modifications, motivated only by the desire to catch up on some of the technical and infrastructural changes in the world since 1994.

Current state of play

TEI P4 has been through a number of automatic and semi-automatic procedures, most of them documented in TEI ED W69, and TEI ED W70. At the conclusion of those processes, we have:

  • New versions of all TEI ODD files which use XML syntax and which conform with an XML DTD made from the original TEI ODD dtd;
  • XSL-T stylesheets which can be used to generate the DTD fragments and/or readable text in HTML or PDF from the foregoing;
  • a complete set of new TEI DTD fragments, which can be parameterised for use in either SGML or XML;
  • a text of P4 in which the examples have been systematically checked and converted to use XML syntax, and in which all explicit references to SGML have been systematically reviewed and changed to reflect the new status of the Guidelines.

Work to be done

In the opinion of the editors, the following work remains to be done before we will have a publishable version of the P4 Guidelines:

  1. all of the text needs to be proof-read for inadvertently introduced or long-lurking typos;
  2. the `gentle guide' to SGML needs to be rewritten to make clear which parts of it relate to XML and which to SGML;
  3. the recommendations in chapters 4 and 25 about character encoding issues need to be completely overhauled and rethought in the light of Unicode;
  4. the formal grammar of SGML needs to be removed, or either supplemented or replaced by an equivalent formal grammar for XML;
  5. discussion of SDIF and other defunct standards needs to be replaced or removed;
  6. discussion of at least some of the following is needed: XML Schema, Unicode, Namespaces, XPath, Xpointer, Xlink, XInclude, RDF, Fragment spec, MathML, Dublin Core, URLs vs. FPIs at various places in the text;
  7. the bibliography needs to be brought up to date.

Much of the above work is fairly easy and uncontentious. Other parts are more problematic, requiring either larger investments of time and effort than are readily available or requiring wider consultation with the TEI community. In particular, it seems to us that the character encoding recommendations (primarily chap 4 but also 25, 37) have been largely overtaken by events, and are thus overdue for review. We propose that a workgroup be chartered by the Board to address this problem as soon as possible, in advance of the existence of the TEI Council which should formally ratify its work. A separate document (TEI EDW72) proposes a charge and suggests an initial membership for this workgroup. The group will be asked to produce a preliminary report in time for the first TEI members meeting in mid October, by when it is hoped that a significant proportion of the remainder of the workplan specified in the next section will also be completed.

Editorial work plan

We list below a very minimal workplan, subject to review and reaction from the Board and from the panel of proof readers we hope to recruit.

  • Redraft Gentle Guide to include XML: LB to do by mid-Sept
  • Introduce discussion of Xlink and related standards into chapter 14 (linking and alignment): SDR to do by mid-Sept
  • Recruit volunteer proof readers, allocate chapters to them, act on their feedback: LB/SDR to complete by start October.
  • Revise bibliography: volunteer needed
  • Review chapter 39 (formal grammar): volunteer needed
  • Review chapter 28, 29, 30 (conformance, modification, interchange) for significant content changes: volunteer needed
  • Propose new material on Dublin Core, RDF and other relevant metadata standards for inclusion in chapters 5 and 24 (the Header): volunteer needed;
  • Propose material on MathML (and namespaces?) for chapter 22 (Tables, formulae, and graphics): volunteer needed
  • Revise chap 27 (Tagset doc) to include specification of the ODD system as used in P4 : LB to do, but not any time soon
  • Review discussion of CONCUR in chapter 31
